review.title: An Approach to Model Checking of Multi-agent Data Analysis
review.abstract: The paper presents an approach to verification of a multi-agent data analysis algorithm. We base correct simulation of the multi-agent system by a finite integer model. For verification we use model checking tool SPIN. Protocols of agents are written in Promela language and properties of the multi-agent data analysis system are expressed in logic LTL. We run several experiments with SPIN and the model.

metadata.title: An Approach to Model Checking of Multi-agent Data Analysis

sections.heading: An Approach to Model Checking of Multi-agent Data
sections.text: AnalysisNatalia Garanina Eugene Bodin A.P. Ershov Institute of Informatics Systems, Novosibirsk, Russia к garanina, bodin, lena @ iis.nsk.suElena SidorovaThe paper presents an approach for verification of a multi-agent data analysis algorithm. We are based on the correct simulation of the multi-agent system by a finite integer model. For verification we use the model test tool SPIN. The protocols of the agents are written in the language Promela and the properties of the multi-agent data analysis system are expressed in logic LTL. We perform several experiments with SPIN and the model.

sections.text: 14. if evaluated (iri) then {15. send | Rul | + 2 to C; 16. send (Rl, iri) to (o1) i and (o2) i; 17. forall R еRul send (Rl, i) to R;} 18. send − 1 to C;}} informal description of the rule agent protocol. It has two parallel subprocesses: the processing of incoming data by instance agents (ProcInput) and the generation of the result (ProcResult). The processing of incoming data includes (1) the creation of argument vectors and (2) the sending of argument vectors or the termination to ProcResult. The processing of the resulting result includes (1) the verification of the conformity of arguments and argument vectors, (2) the generation of the result that represents new attribute values of some information agents and / or new information agents with their positions, and (3) the determination of the rule agents for the new data being given to them by the rule agent immediately after the change of the new information agent is reported to them.

Act = 0; 2. while (Input = / 0) {} 3. while (true) {4. if (Input 6 = / 0) then Act = Act + get mess (Input); 5. if (Input = / 0 and Act = 0) then break;}

sections.heading: 6. send STOP to all;
sections.text: The following sentence is a direct consequence of sentence 1 from [7]: sentence 1 Multi-Agent System MDA terminates and the agent controller determines the termination time correctly. Proof of the first part is based on the finiteness of the input data and the reasonable assumption that rules of ontology and data processing cannot generate endless new information; the second assertion is based on timely notification of activities of information and rule agents.

sections.heading: 5 Conclusion
sections.text: We are simulating our model in SPIN for fifty main agents and the agent controller (138130 steps). SPIN seems to be able to comprehensively verify the termination accuracy and operability characteristics for twelve main agents, and bitstate verification for eighteen main agents. The latter verification required 25 minutes of a computer with an Intel Celeron (R) CPU running at 2.6 GHz and about 1 GB of RAM. Both characteristics are satisfactory in this model. Termination characteristics have not yet been verified. At this stage of our research, we are not dealing with competition or collaboration of instance agents to resolve ambiguities. We plan to enrich the agents with capabilities for this type of interactions, develop ambiguity-resolving algorithms and verify their characteristics such as correcting interactions, etc.

send STOP to all; The following proposition is straight consequence of Proposition 1 from [7]: Proposition 1 Multi-agent system MDA terminates and the agent-controller determines the termination moment correctly.
The proposition is proved in [7].
For formal model checking of our multi-agent data analysis system we choose popular and well-developed model checking tool SPIN[8].

metadata.abstractText: The paper presents an approach to verification of a multi-agent data analysis algorithm. We base correct simulation of the multi-agent system by a finite integer model. For verification we use model checking tool SPIN. Protocols of agents are written in Promela language and properties of the multiagent data analysis system are expressed in logic LTL. We run several experiments with SPIN and the model.
